useCases.title: Retail Pricing
useCases.description: Determine selling prices for products by applying standard industry markup percentages to wholesale costs.

useCases.title: Menu Pricing
useCases.description: Restaurants use markup calculations to price dishes based on ingredient costs while ensuring profitability.

useCases.title: Service Pricing
useCases.description: Consultants and contractors mark up material costs when billing clients to cover overhead and profit.

useCases.title: Competitive Analysis
useCases.description: Reverse-calculate competitor markup percentages by comparing their prices to estimated costs.

seoTips: Standard retail markup is typically 50-100% (keystone pricing is 100% or 2x cost)
Convert markup to margin for financial reporting: Margin = Markup / (1 + Markup)
Higher markups are justified by value-added services, exclusivity, or convenience
Consider price elasticity - some products tolerate higher markups than others
Review markup regularly as supplier costs and market conditions change

commonMistakes.title: Confusing Markup with Margin
commonMistakes.description: A 50% markup yields only 33% margin. Markup is based on cost; margin is based on selling price. They're not interchangeable.

commonMistakes.title: Forgetting All Costs
commonMistakes.description: Only marking up product cost ignores shipping, storage, handling, and overhead. Include all costs in your base for accurate pricing.

commonMistakes.title: Using Same Markup for All Products
commonMistakes.description: Different products have different price sensitivity and competition. Vary markup based on market conditions and product category.

commonMistakes.title: Not Accounting for Discounts
commonMistakes.description: If you plan to offer discounts or promotions, build that into your base markup to maintain profitability.

faqs.question: What's the difference between markup and margin?
faqs.answer: Markup is added to cost: Selling Price = Cost + Markup. Margin is part of price: Selling Price = Cost / (1 - Margin). 100% markup = 50% margin.

faqs.question: What is keystone pricing?
faqs.answer: Keystone pricing is a 100% markup (2x cost). A $50 cost item sells for $100. It's a traditional retail benchmark, though many industries use different standards.

faqs.question: How do I calculate markup from selling price?
faqs.answer: Markup % = ((Selling Price - Cost) / Cost) × 100. If cost is $40 and price is $60: (60-40)/40 × 100 = 50% markup.

faqs.question: What markup should I use for my industry?
faqs.answer: Varies by industry: Grocery 5-15%, Clothing 100-300%, Jewelry 100-400%, Electronics 30-50%, Restaurants 300% on food. Research your specific market.

faqs.question: How do I convert markup to profit margin?
faqs.answer: Margin = Markup / (1 + Markup). For 50% markup: 0.50 / 1.50 = 33.3% margin. For 100% markup: 1.00 / 2.00 = 50% margin.

howItWorks.formula: Total = Subtotal × (1 + Tax Rate / 100)
howItWorks.explanation: Sales tax is a percentage added to the subtotal at the point of sale. Unlike VAT, sales tax is only collected once at the final consumer sale. Rates vary by state, county, and city in the US, and by region in other countries.

useCases.title: Budget Planning

useCases.title: Receipt Verification
useCases.description: Verify that sales tax was calculated correctly on purchases and invoices.

useCases.title: Multi-State Commerce
useCases.description: Calculate correct tax amounts for sales to customers in different tax jurisdictions.

seoTips: US sales tax varies from 0% (Oregon, Delaware) to 10%+ (some California cities)
Many states exempt groceries, medicine, and clothing from sales tax
Online sellers may need to collect tax in multiple states based on economic nexus
Always verify current tax rates - they change frequently
Consider use tax for out-of-state purchases where sales tax wasn't collected

commonMistakes.title: Using Statewide Rate Only
commonMistakes.description: Total sales tax often includes state, county, and city components. Use the combined rate for your specific location.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Exemptions
commonMistakes.description: Many items like groceries, medicine, or clothing may be exempt or taxed at reduced rates. Know your local exemptions.

commonMistakes.title: Not Tracking Rate Changes
commonMistakes.description: Tax rates change frequently. Ensure your calculations use current rates, especially for business applications.

commonMistakes.title: Confusing Sales Tax with VAT
commonMistakes.description: Sales tax is charged only at final sale to consumers. VAT is charged at each production stage with input credits.

faqs.question: How do I find my local sales tax rate?
faqs.answer: Check your state's department of revenue website. Rates vary by state, county, and city. Some areas have special district taxes too.

faqs.question: What is the average US sales tax rate?
faqs.answer: Average combined state and local rate is about 7.12%. Ranges from 0% (5 states have no sales tax) to over 10% in some cities.

faqs.question: Do I need to collect sales tax for online sales?
faqs.answer: Usually yes, if you have economic nexus in the buyer's state. Rules vary by state - research or use automated tax software.

faqs.question: How do I extract tax from a tax-inclusive price?
faqs.answer: Subtotal = Total / (1 + Tax Rate). For $107 with 7% tax: $107 / 1.07 = $100 subtotal, $7 tax.

faqs.question: Are there items exempt from sales tax?
faqs.answer: Varies by state. Common exemptions include groceries, prescription drugs, medical equipment, and sometimes clothing. Check your state's rules.

howItWorks.title: How Depreciation Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: Straight-Line: (Cost - Salvage) / Useful Life
howItWorks.explanation: Depreciation allocates an asset's cost over its useful life. Straight-line spreads cost evenly each year. Declining balance methods front-load depreciation, providing larger deductions in early years. The method chosen affects tax benefits and financial statements.

useCases.title: Tax Planning
useCases.description: Calculate depreciation deductions to reduce taxable income and plan for tax obligations each year.

useCases.title: Financial Statements
useCases.description: Prepare accurate financial statements by properly accounting for asset depreciation over time.

useCases.title: Asset Management
useCases.description: Track book values of business assets for insurance, sale decisions, and replacement planning.

useCases.title: Capital Budgeting
useCases.description: Include depreciation in investment analysis to understand true cost and cash flow impact of capital purchases.

seoTips: MACRS is required for US tax depreciation - IRS publishes specific recovery periods
Accelerated methods like double-declining provide larger early deductions
Book depreciation can differ from tax depreciation - track both
Section 179 allows immediate expensing of qualifying assets up to limits
Bonus depreciation may allow 100% first-year deduction for certain assets

commonMistakes.title: Using Wrong Useful Life
commonMistakes.description: IRS specifies depreciation periods for tax purposes. Using arbitrary periods results in incorrect tax deductions.

commonMistakes.title: Forgetting Salvage Value
commonMistakes.description: Assets often retain some value at end of useful life. Depreciating to zero when salvage value exists overstates depreciation.

commonMistakes.title: Mixing Book and Tax Methods
commonMistakes.description: Book depreciation for financial statements may differ from tax depreciation. Track both separately for accurate reporting.

commonMistakes.title: Not Considering Bonus Depreciation
commonMistakes.description: Special tax provisions like Section 179 and bonus depreciation can allow faster write-offs. Consult a tax professional.

faqs.question: What is straight-line depreciation?
faqs.answer: Straight-line spreads depreciation evenly over useful life. Formula: (Cost - Salvage) / Years. Simple but may not reflect actual asset value decline.

faqs.question: When should I use accelerated depreciation?
faqs.answer: When you want larger tax deductions early, or when assets lose value quickly in early years (vehicles, technology). Matches expense to actual value decline.

faqs.question: What is MACRS depreciation?
faqs.answer: Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System - the US tax method. IRS specifies recovery periods and depreciation rates for different asset classes.

faqs.question: How does depreciation affect taxes?
faqs.answer: Depreciation is a non-cash expense that reduces taxable income. Higher depreciation means lower taxes but also lower reported profit.

faqs.question: Can I depreciate land?
faqs.answer: No. Land doesn't wear out so it cannot be depreciated. Only buildings and improvements on land are depreciable.

howItWorks.title: How NPV Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: NPV = Σ(Cash Flow / (1 + r)^t) - Initial Investment
howItWorks.explanation: NPV calculates the present value of all future cash flows, discounted at a required rate of return, minus the initial investment. A positive NPV indicates the investment should generate value; negative NPV suggests the investment will destroy value.

steps.text: Enter the initial investment amount

steps.name: Step 2

steps.name: Step 4

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: NPV = sum of discounted cash flows minus initial investment

useCases.title: Capital Budgeting
useCases.description: Evaluate whether to proceed with major capital expenditures like equipment purchases or facility expansions.

useCases.title: Project Selection
useCases.description: Compare multiple potential projects with different cash flow patterns to allocate limited capital effectively.

useCases.title: Acquisition Valuation
useCases.description: Determine the fair value of a business by discounting its projected future cash flows to present value.

useCases.title: Investment Analysis
useCases.description: Assess real estate, stocks, or other investments by comparing NPV of expected returns to alternative opportunities.

seoTips: Choose your discount rate carefully - it significantly impacts NPV results
Use company's WACC (Weighted Average Cost of Capital) as discount rate for corporate projects
Always include terminal value for projects with cash flows beyond your projection period
Positive NPV doesn't guarantee success - consider qualitative factors too
Run sensitivity analysis on key assumptions to understand risk range

commonMistakes.title: Using Wrong Discount Rate
commonMistakes.description: The discount rate should reflect the risk of the cash flows. Using a rate too low overstates NPV; too high understates it.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Terminal Value
commonMistakes.description: For ongoing businesses or long-lived assets, failing to include terminal value significantly underestimates NPV.

commonMistakes.title: Overly Optimistic Cash Flows
commonMistakes.description: Projecting unrealistic cash flow growth leads to misleading NPV. Use conservative, evidence-based estimates.

commonMistakes.title: Not Considering Inflation
commonMistakes.description: Either use nominal cash flows with nominal discount rate, or real cash flows with real rate. Mixing them creates errors.

faqs.question: What does positive NPV mean?
faqs.answer: Positive NPV means the investment is expected to generate more value than its cost. It should increase company/investor wealth and is generally worth pursuing.

faqs.question: What discount rate should I use?
faqs.answer: Use your cost of capital or required rate of return. For companies, WACC (7-12% typical). For personal investments, consider opportunity cost and risk.

faqs.question: What's the difference between NPV and IRR?
faqs.answer: NPV gives dollar value created; IRR gives percentage return. NPV is generally preferred because it measures absolute value creation, not just rate.

faqs.question: Can NPV be negative?
faqs.answer: Yes. Negative NPV means the investment is expected to destroy value - the present value of returns is less than the cost. Generally avoid negative NPV projects.

faqs.question: How do I include terminal value in NPV?
faqs.answer: Estimate ongoing value at end of projection period (often using perpetuity formula or exit multiple), then discount that terminal value back to present.

irr.title: IRR Calculator
irr.description: Calculate Internal Rate of Return for investment projects.

inputs.initial_investment_tooltip: The upfront cost of the investment

howItWorks.title: How IRR Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: IRR = Discount rate where NPV equals zero
howItWorks.explanation: IRR (Internal Rate of Return) is the discount rate that makes the net present value of all cash flows equal to zero. It represents the annualized rate of return on an investment, allowing comparison between projects of different sizes and durations.

steps.text: Enter the initial investment amount (as a negative cash flow)

steps.name: Step 2
steps.text: Input expected cash flows for each future year

steps.name: Step 5
steps.text: Compare IRR to your required return or cost of capital

useCases.title: Project Ranking
useCases.description: Rank multiple investment opportunities by their IRR to identify highest-return options for capital allocation.

useCases.title: Investment Hurdle Rate
useCases.description: Compare project IRR to company's hurdle rate (cost of capital) to determine if investment meets return requirements.

useCases.title: Private Equity Returns
useCases.description: Calculate and report returns to investors in private equity and venture capital investments.

useCases.title: Real Estate Analysis
useCases.description: Evaluate property investments by calculating IRR including purchase, rental income, and sale proceeds.

seoTips: IRR above your cost of capital indicates value-creating investment
Compare IRR to NPV - they can give different rankings for mutually exclusive projects
Be cautious with IRR for projects with alternating positive/negative cash flows
Modified IRR (MIRR) addresses reinvestment rate assumptions
Use IRR for comparing similar-sized projects; NPV for absolute value creation

commonMistakes.title: Assuming Reinvestment at IRR
commonMistakes.description: IRR assumes cash flows are reinvested at the IRR rate, which may be unrealistic for high-IRR projects.

commonMistakes.title: Multiple IRR Problem
commonMistakes.description: Projects with alternating positive and negative cash flows can have multiple IRRs, making interpretation difficult.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Scale
commonMistakes.description: A small project with high IRR may create less value than a large project with lower IRR. Consider NPV alongside IRR.

commonMistakes.title: Comparing Different Duration Projects
commonMistakes.description: A 2-year project with 20% IRR isn't directly comparable to a 10-year project with 15% IRR. Consider total value creation.

faqs.question: What is a good IRR?
faqs.answer: Depends on risk and alternatives. Generally: above risk-free rate (3-5%) is minimum, above cost of capital (8-12%) is acceptable, above 15-20% is good for most investments.

faqs.question: What's the difference between IRR and ROI?
faqs.answer: ROI is simple total return (profit/cost). IRR accounts for time value of money and timing of cash flows. IRR is annualized; ROI is total return regardless of period.

faqs.question: When should I use IRR vs NPV?
faqs.answer: Use both. IRR tells return rate; NPV tells dollar value created. For mutually exclusive projects, NPV is preferred. For quick comparison, IRR is useful.

faqs.question: What is Modified IRR (MIRR)?
faqs.answer: MIRR assumes cash flows are reinvested at cost of capital rather than at IRR. It's more realistic for high-IRR projects and avoids multiple IRR issues.

faqs.question: Why can't IRR be calculated for my project?
faqs.answer: IRR requires at least one sign change in cash flows (typically negative investment followed by positive returns). All positive or all negative flows have no IRR.

howItWorks.formula: Net Cash Flow = Total Cash Inflows - Total Cash Outflows
howItWorks.explanation: Cash flow analysis tracks actual money movement in and out of a business. Unlike profit (which includes non-cash items), cash flow shows real liquidity. Positive cash flow means more money coming in than going out; negative cash flow indicates a cash drain.

useCases.description: Monitor cash position to ensure the business can pay bills, employees, and suppliers on time.

useCases.title: Cash Forecasting
useCases.description: Project future cash position based on expected inflows and outflows to plan for shortfalls or surpluses.

useCases.title: Investment Timing
useCases.description: Identify periods of cash surplus when investments can be made or excess cash deployed.

useCases.title: Financing Decisions
useCases.description: Determine when and how much financing is needed based on cash flow projections.

seoTips: Cash flow is king - profitable businesses can fail without adequate cash
Separate operating, investing, and financing cash flows for better analysis
Monitor cash conversion cycle to improve working capital efficiency
Forecast cash flow 13 weeks ahead for short-term planning
Positive net income doesn't guarantee positive cash flow

commonMistakes.title: Confusing Profit with Cash Flow
commonMistakes.description: Net income includes non-cash items like depreciation and accounts receivable. A profitable business can run out of cash.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Timing
commonMistakes.description: Revenue is recognized when earned, but cash arrives when collected. Track actual cash receipt dates, not invoice dates.

commonMistakes.title: Overlooking Seasonal Variations
commonMistakes.description: Annual cash flow may be positive while individual months are negative. Plan for seasonal patterns.

commonMistakes.title: Not Including All Cash Items
commonMistakes.description: Don't forget loan payments, tax payments, owner draws, and one-time expenses that affect cash but may not appear on income statement.

faqs.question: What's the difference between cash flow and profit?
faqs.answer: Profit includes non-cash items like depreciation and accrued revenue. Cash flow tracks actual money movement. A company can be profitable but cash-poor, or cash-rich but unprofitable.

faqs.question: What is operating cash flow?
faqs.answer: Cash from core business operations - customer payments minus operating expenses. It excludes investing (buying/selling assets) and financing (loans, equity) activities.

faqs.question: How can I improve cash flow?
faqs.answer: Collect receivables faster, negotiate longer payment terms with suppliers, reduce inventory levels, lease instead of buy equipment, and manage growth pace.

faqs.question: What is free cash flow?
faqs.answer: Operating cash flow minus capital expenditures. It's cash available for dividends, debt reduction, or reinvestment after maintaining operations.

faqs.question: How often should I review cash flow?
faqs.answer: Weekly for short-term management, monthly for trends, quarterly for strategic planning. More frequently during tight cash periods.

howItWorks.explanation: Inflation erodes purchasing power over time. The calculator shows how much more you'll need in the future to buy what a certain amount buys today. Conversely, it shows how much less your current savings will be worth in real terms.

useCases.title: Retirement Planning
useCases.description: Calculate how much you'll need in retirement to maintain current lifestyle, accounting for inflation over 20-30 years.

useCases.title: Investment Returns
useCases.description: Calculate real returns by subtracting inflation from nominal investment gains to understand true wealth growth.

useCases.title: Salary Negotiations
useCases.description: Determine the raise needed to maintain purchasing power or the real value of salary increases over time.

useCases.title: Long-Term Contracts
useCases.description: Price long-term contracts and agreements accounting for expected cost increases due to inflation.

seoTips: Historical US inflation averages about 3% annually; plan for 2-4% in projections
Rule of 72: divide 72 by inflation rate to see years for prices to double
Real return = nominal return - inflation rate (approximation)
High inflation periods (1970s-80s) saw 10%+ rates; low periods under 2%
Consider healthcare and education inflation rates, which exceed general inflation

commonMistakes.title: Using Short-Term Rates for Long-Term Planning
commonMistakes.description: Current inflation rates may be temporary. Use long-term averages (2-3%) for retirement and multi-decade planning.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Inflation Entirely
commonMistakes.description: Planning retirement needs at today's costs without inflation adjustment leads to severe shortfalls.

commonMistakes.title: Not Considering Sector-Specific Inflation
commonMistakes.description: Healthcare, education, and housing often inflate faster than general CPI. Account for your specific expense mix.

commonMistakes.title: Confusing Nominal and Real Values
commonMistakes.description: Investment returns, salaries, and prices are usually quoted nominally. Subtract inflation for real (inflation-adjusted) values.

faqs.question: What is a realistic inflation rate to use?
faqs.answer: For long-term planning, 2.5-3% is reasonable based on historical averages. Central banks typically target 2%. Adjust based on current economic conditions.

faqs.question: How does inflation affect my savings?
faqs.answer: If your savings earn less than inflation, you're losing purchasing power. $10,000 at 1% interest with 3% inflation loses real value each year.

faqs.question: What is the Rule of 72 for inflation?
faqs.answer: Divide 72 by the inflation rate to see how many years until prices double. At 3% inflation: 72/3 = 24 years for prices to double.

faqs.question: Should I invest differently based on inflation?
faqs.answer: Yes. During high inflation, consider TIPS, I-bonds, real estate, commodities, and stocks. Cash and fixed bonds lose value in high inflation.

faqs.question: What is deflation and how is it different?
faqs.answer: Deflation is negative inflation - prices decrease over time. Rare but harmful to economies. Your money gains purchasing power but economic activity slows.

howItWorks.explanation: The salary calculator converts compensation between different pay frequencies: annual, monthly, bi-weekly, weekly, and hourly. It accounts for work hours and weeks to provide accurate conversions for comparing job offers or budgeting.

seoTips: Standard full-time is 40 hours/week, 52 weeks/year = 2,080 hours annually
Account for unpaid time off when converting - 50 weeks may be more realistic than 52
Gross salary differs from net (take-home) - factor in taxes and deductions
Benefits have value too - healthcare, 401k match add to total compensation
Bi-weekly pay means 26 paychecks/year, not 24 (important for budgeting)

commonMistakes.title: Forgetting Benefits Value
commonMistakes.description: A lower salary with good benefits (health insurance, 401k match) may exceed a higher salary without benefits in total value.

commonMistakes.title: Confusing Bi-Weekly and Semi-Monthly
commonMistakes.description: Bi-weekly is every 2 weeks (26 pay periods). Semi-monthly is twice per month (24 periods). The difference adds up.

commonMistakes.title: Not Accounting for Taxes
commonMistakes.description: Gross salary isn't what you take home. Factor in federal, state, local taxes and deductions for realistic budgeting.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Overtime Eligibility
commonMistakes.description: Salaried employees may be exempt from overtime. Hourly workers earning overtime may exceed comparable salaries.

faqs.question: How do I convert annual salary to hourly?
faqs.answer: Divide annual salary by total work hours. For standard full-time: Annual / 2,080 hours. $52,000 / 2,080 = $25/hour.

faqs.question: Is bi-weekly the same as twice a month?
faqs.answer: No. Bi-weekly is every 2 weeks (26 paychecks/year). Semi-monthly is twice per month (24 paychecks/year). Bi-weekly pays slightly more over a year.

faqs.question: What's considered a good salary?
faqs.answer: Depends on location and industry. US median is about $60,000. Consider cost of living - $80K in NYC may equal $50K in the Midwest.

faqs.question: How do I account for unpaid time off?
faqs.answer: Reduce weeks per year. If you take 2 weeks unpaid vacation, use 50 weeks instead of 52 for more accurate hourly conversion.

faqs.question: Should I include bonuses in salary calculations?
faqs.answer: For budgeting, use base salary only since bonuses aren't guaranteed. For total compensation comparison, include expected bonuses.

seoTips: Standard calculation uses 2,080 hours (40 hours × 52 weeks)
For freelancing, add 30-40% to account for self-employment taxes and benefits
Consider actual hours worked, not just scheduled hours, for true rate
Include unpaid overtime for realistic comparison between jobs
Factor in commute time for total time cost of employment

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Unpaid Work
commonMistakes.description: Many salaried employees work beyond 40 hours. Include actual hours worked for true hourly rate.

commonMistakes.title: Not Adjusting for Benefits
commonMistakes.description: When comparing to freelance work, add 25-40% to cover healthcare, retirement, and self-employment taxes you'd pay.

commonMistakes.title: Using Wrong Weeks Per Year
commonMistakes.description: If you have unpaid vacation time, reduce weeks accordingly. Using 52 weeks overstates hourly rate.

commonMistakes.title: Comparing Gross to Net
commonMistakes.description: Ensure you're comparing like to like - both gross or both net. Mixing leads to inaccurate comparisons.

faqs.question: How many work hours are in a year?
faqs.answer: Standard full-time is 2,080 hours (40 hours × 52 weeks). Excluding vacation and holidays: 1,920-2,000 hours is more realistic.

faqs.question: What's a good hourly rate?
faqs.answer: Depends on industry and location. US average is about $30/hour. Tech and specialized fields can be $50-150+/hour.

faqs.question: How do I set freelance rates from salary?
faqs.answer: Take your hourly equivalent and add 30-50% for self-employment taxes, healthcare, retirement, equipment, and downtime between projects.

faqs.question: Should I include bonuses in the calculation?
faqs.answer: For guaranteed bonuses, yes. For performance-based bonuses, calculate both with and without for range. Don't include uncertain income.

faqs.question: Is hourly or salary better?
faqs.answer: Depends on circumstances. Hourly guarantees payment for all hours worked including overtime. Salary offers stability but may mean unpaid overtime.

howItWorks.title: How Overtime Pay Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: Total Pay = (Regular Hours × Rate) + (Overtime Hours × Rate × Multiplier)
howItWorks.explanation: Overtime pay compensates workers for hours beyond the standard work week, typically 40 hours in the US. The Fair Labor Standards Act requires non-exempt employees receive at least 1.5x their regular rate for overtime hours.

seoTips: FLSA requires 1.5x pay for hours over 40/week for non-exempt employees
Some states (California) require daily overtime after 8 hours
Salaried employees may be exempt from overtime depending on duties and salary
Double time is often required for hours over 60/week or on holidays
Keep records of all hours worked to ensure proper overtime compensation

commonMistakes.title: Not Knowing Exemption Status
commonMistakes.description: Many employees misunderstand whether they're exempt or non-exempt. Salary alone doesn't determine exemption - job duties matter.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring State Laws
commonMistakes.description: Some states have stricter overtime laws than federal FLSA. California requires daily overtime; some states have no overtime laws.

commonMistakes.title: Calculating on Wrong Base Rate
commonMistakes.description: Overtime should be calculated on the regular rate of pay including shift differentials and some bonuses, not just base rate.

commonMistakes.title: Averaging Hours Across Weeks
commonMistakes.description: Overtime is calculated weekly, not averaged. Working 50 hours one week and 30 the next still requires OT pay for the 50-hour week.

faqs.question: Who is entitled to overtime pay?
faqs.answer: Non-exempt employees working over 40 hours/week. Exemptions apply to some salaried professionals, executives, and administrators based on job duties.

faqs.question: What is time and a half?
faqs.answer: 1.5 times your regular hourly rate. If you earn $20/hour, time and a half is $30/hour for overtime hours.

faqs.question: Can my employer force overtime?
faqs.answer: Generally yes, employers can require overtime as a condition of employment, subject to labor laws and union agreements.

faqs.question: Is overtime taxed differently?
faqs.answer: Overtime is taxed at your normal income rate. It may seem higher due to withholding, but annual tax is the same rate.

faqs.question: What is double time?
faqs.answer: 2x regular pay, required in some states (California) for hours over 12/day or work on the 7th consecutive day.

howItWorks.title: How Bonus Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: Bonus = Base Salary × (Target Bonus % / 100) × Performance Factor
howItWorks.explanation: Performance bonuses are calculated as a percentage of base salary, adjusted by a performance multiplier. Target bonus represents expected payout for meeting expectations; the performance factor scales this up or down based on actual performance.

seoTips: Typical target bonuses: Entry-level 5-10%, Mid-level 10-20%, Senior 20-40%, Executive 50%+
Performance factors usually range from 0% (no bonus) to 150-200% for top performers
Bonus is typically paid annually, but some companies pay quarterly
Company performance often affects bonus pool independently of individual performance
Signing bonuses and spot bonuses are separate from annual performance bonuses

commonMistakes.title: Assuming Bonus is Guaranteed
commonMistakes.description: Discretionary bonuses depend on company and individual performance. Budget based on base salary, not expected bonus.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Tax Impact
commonMistakes.description: Bonuses are often withheld at a higher rate (22% federal supplemental rate) though total tax is the same as regular income.

commonMistakes.title: Not Understanding Performance Criteria
commonMistakes.description: Clarify how performance is evaluated and what factors determine the multiplier. Subjective vs. objective criteria matter.

commonMistakes.title: Overlooking Company Performance Component
commonMistakes.description: Many bonus structures include company-wide performance factors. Strong personal performance with poor company results may still yield reduced bonus.

faqs.question: What is a typical performance bonus?
faqs.answer: Varies by role and company. Entry-level: 5-10% of salary. Manager: 15-25%. Director/VP: 25-50%. Executive: 50-100%+.

faqs.question: When are bonuses typically paid?
faqs.answer: Most commonly Q1 of the following year (January-March). Some companies pay quarterly or upon project completion.

faqs.question: Are bonuses taxed higher than salary?
faqs.answer: Same tax rate, but federal withholding uses 22% supplemental rate. You may owe more or get a refund at tax time.

faqs.question: What if I leave before bonus payout?
faqs.answer: Depends on company policy. Many require employment on payout date. Some prorate for partial year. Check your employment agreement.

faqs.question: How can I maximize my bonus?
faqs.answer: Understand evaluation criteria, document achievements, align with company goals, and have performance discussions before review time.

howItWorks.title: How EOQ Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: EOQ = sqrt(2 × Annual Demand × Order Cost / Holding Cost)
howItWorks.explanation: Economic Order Quantity finds the optimal order size that minimizes total inventory costs. It balances ordering costs (which decrease with larger orders) against holding costs (which increase with larger inventory). The EOQ is where these two cost curves intersect.

seoTips: EOQ assumes constant demand - adjust for seasonal variations
Holding cost typically ranges 15-30% of item value annually
Include all ordering costs: shipping, handling, inspection, and administrative
EOQ is a starting point - adjust for constraints like storage space and cash flow
Review and recalculate EOQ when costs or demand patterns change significantly

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Demand Variability
commonMistakes.description: EOQ assumes constant demand. For variable demand, add safety stock and consider seasonal adjustments.

commonMistakes.title: Underestimating Holding Costs
commonMistakes.description: Include all costs: storage space, insurance, shrinkage, obsolescence, capital tied up, and handling.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Quantity Discounts
commonMistakes.description: EOQ doesn't account for volume discounts. Compare total cost at EOQ to cost at discount price breaks.

commonMistakes.title: Not Considering Lead Time
commonMistakes.description: EOQ determines how much to order, but reorder point depends on lead time. Calculate both together.

faqs.question: What is Economic Order Quantity?
faqs.answer: EOQ is the optimal order size that minimizes total inventory costs (ordering + holding). It's where the cost of placing orders equals the cost of holding inventory.

faqs.question: What costs are included in ordering cost?
faqs.answer: Fixed costs per order: purchase order processing, shipping/freight, receiving and inspection, invoice processing. Does not include the product cost itself.

faqs.question: What costs are included in holding cost?
faqs.answer: Annual cost to store one unit: storage space, insurance, taxes, obsolescence, shrinkage, opportunity cost of capital. Typically 15-30% of item value.

faqs.question: Does EOQ work for all products?
faqs.answer: Best for stable, continuous demand items. Less suitable for seasonal products, new products, or items with highly variable demand.

faqs.question: How often should I recalculate EOQ?
faqs.answer: When demand, ordering costs, or holding costs change significantly. At minimum, review annually or when making major supply chain changes.

howItWorks.title: How Inventory Turnover Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: Inventory Turnover = Cost of Goods Sold / Average Inventory
howItWorks.explanation: Inventory turnover measures how many times a company sells and replaces its inventory during a period. Higher turnover indicates efficient inventory management - products sell quickly without sitting in warehouses. Lower turnover may indicate overstocking or slow sales.

seoTips: Typical turnover varies by industry: Grocery 12-15x, Retail 6-8x, Manufacturing 3-5x
Days Sales of Inventory (DSI) = 365 / Turnover Ratio shows average days to sell inventory
Compare turnover year-over-year and to industry averages for meaningful analysis
Higher isn't always better - too high may indicate stockouts and lost sales
Track turnover by product category for actionable insights

commonMistakes.title: Using Revenue Instead of COGS
commonMistakes.description: Always use Cost of Goods Sold, not revenue. Revenue includes profit margin and distorts the ratio.

commonMistakes.title: Point-in-Time Inventory
commonMistakes.description: Use average inventory (beginning + ending / 2), not just ending inventory. Seasonal variations affect point-in-time values.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Seasonality
commonMistakes.description: Seasonal businesses may have different turnover at different times. Analyze full-year and compare periods consistently.

commonMistakes.title: Cross-Industry Comparisons
commonMistakes.description: Turnover varies dramatically by industry. Compare only within your sector for meaningful benchmarking.

faqs.question: What is a good inventory turnover ratio?
faqs.answer: Depends on industry. Grocery: 12-15x. Apparel: 4-6x. Furniture: 3-4x. Electronics: 6-8x. Compare to your specific industry average.

faqs.question: How do I calculate days to sell inventory?
faqs.answer: DSI = 365 / Inventory Turnover. If turnover is 6x, DSI = 365/6 = 61 days average to sell inventory.

faqs.question: Is higher or lower inventory turnover better?
faqs.answer: Generally higher is better (efficient inventory management), but too high may mean stockouts. Balance efficiency with service levels.

faqs.question: How can I improve inventory turnover?
faqs.answer: Reduce slow-moving items, improve demand forecasting, negotiate smaller/frequent deliveries, run promotions on old stock, and optimize reorder points.

faqs.question: What if my turnover is too low?
faqs.answer: Low turnover ties up cash and increases holding costs. Review product mix, identify obsolete inventory, consider markdowns, and improve sales efforts.

seoTips: Benefits typically add 25-40% to base wages - use at least 25% in calculations
Don't forget employer portion of payroll taxes (7.65% Social Security/Medicare)
Overhead includes workspace, equipment, software, insurance, and management time
Billable rates should be 2-3x fully-loaded labor cost for profitable services
Track actual labor costs vs estimates to improve future budgeting accuracy

commonMistakes.title: Using Only Base Wages
commonMistakes.description: Base wage is just the start. Add benefits (25-40%), payroll taxes (7.65%+), and overhead (10-30%) for true cost.

commonMistakes.title: Forgetting Non-Productive Time
commonMistakes.description: Employees don't produce for 100% of paid hours. Account for meetings, training, sick time, and administrative tasks.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Turnover Costs
commonMistakes.description: Hiring and training costs average 50-200% of annual salary. Factor this into long-term labor cost planning.

commonMistakes.title: Not Including All Benefits
commonMistakes.description: Include healthcare, retirement match, PTO, disability, life insurance, and all employer-paid benefits.

faqs.question: What is a fully-loaded labor cost?
faqs.answer: Base wages plus all employer costs: benefits, payroll taxes, workers comp, overhead, and any other costs to employ someone. Typically 1.25-1.5x base wage.

faqs.question: What benefits should I include?
faqs.answer: Health insurance (employer portion), 401k match, PTO value, disability, life insurance, and any other employer-paid benefits.

faqs.question: What overhead should I include?
faqs.answer: Workspace, equipment, software/tools, utilities, HR costs, management time, training, and administrative support.

faqs.question: How do I calculate effective hourly rate?
faqs.answer: Divide annual fully-loaded cost by actual productive hours (typically 1,700-1,900 hours after vacation, sick time, and meetings).

faqs.question: How does this compare to contractors?
faqs.answer: Contractors include their own benefits/overhead in rates. Compare contractor rates to fully-loaded employee cost, not base salary, for fair comparison.

commonMistakes.description: A larger package isn't a better value if half goes to waste. Consider actual usage.

commonMistakes.title: Forgetting Storage Costs
commonMistakes.description: Bulk purchases require storage space. Consider if the savings justify the space used.

commonMistakes.title: Sale Price Assumptions
commonMistakes.description: Compare actual prices today. Regular size on sale may beat bulk price at full price.

faqs.question: Is bigger always cheaper per unit?
faqs.answer: Not always. Sometimes medium sizes or sale items offer better unit prices. Always calculate rather than assume.

faqs.question: How do I compare different units?
faqs.answer: Convert to the same unit first. 1 kg = 35.27 oz = 2.2 lbs. Then divide price by quantity in common units.

faqs.question: Should I always buy the lowest unit price?
faqs.answer: Consider freshness, storage, and whether you'll use it all. Wasted product isn't a bargain regardless of unit price.

faqs.question: Are warehouse clubs always cheaper?
faqs.answer: Not always. Regular stores on sale may beat warehouse prices. Factor in membership cost and compare specific items.

faqs.question: What about quality differences?
faqs.answer: Unit price compares value within similar quality. A premium product may be worth paying more per unit for better quality.

price_elasticity.title: Price Elasticity Calculator
price_elasticity.description: Calculate price elasticity of demand to understand how price changes affect quantity demanded. Essential for pricing strategy and revenue optimization.

inputs.initial_price_tooltip: The original price before the change
inputs.final_price_tooltip: The new price after the change
inputs.initial_quantity_tooltip: Quantity demanded at the initial price
inputs.final_quantity_tooltip: Quantity demanded at the new price

errors.price_must_change: Price must change to calculate elasticity

interpretations.elastic: Demand is sensitive to price changes. A price increase will significantly reduce demand and may lower total revenue.
interpretations.inelastic: Demand is not very sensitive to price changes. Price increases may boost total revenue despite lower sales volume.
interpretations.unitary: Percentage change in quantity equals percentage change in price. Revenue remains relatively stable.
interpretations.perfectly_elastic: Any price increase causes demand to drop to zero. Consumers are extremely price-sensitive.
interpretations.perfectly_inelastic: Demand does not change regardless of price. Typically seen with essential or addictive goods.

results.formula: Elasticity = (% Change in Quantity) / (% Change in Price)

info.title: About Price Elasticity
info.use_case_2: Predict revenue impact of price changes

howItWorks.title: How Price Elasticity Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: Price Elasticity = (% Change in Quantity) / (% Change in Price)
howItWorks.explanation: Price elasticity measures how sensitive demand is to price changes. Elastic demand (>1) means quantity changes more than price - a 10% price increase causes more than 10% drop in sales. Inelastic demand (<1) means quantity changes less than price changes.

useCases.title: Pricing Strategy
useCases.description: Determine whether to raise or lower prices based on how customers respond to price changes.

useCases.title: Revenue Optimization
useCases.description: Identify the price point that maximizes total revenue based on demand elasticity.

useCases.title: Competitive Analysis
useCases.description: Understand how price-sensitive your market is compared to competitors' offerings.

useCases.title: Product Positioning
useCases.description: Decide whether to compete on price (elastic demand) or differentiation (inelastic demand).

seoTips: Elasticity > 1: Elastic demand - lower prices increase revenue
Elasticity < 1: Inelastic demand - higher prices increase revenue
Luxury goods tend to be elastic; necessities tend to be inelastic
Elasticity varies by price point - test at multiple levels
Cross-price elasticity measures response to competitor price changes

commonMistakes.title: Using Too Short a Time Period
commonMistakes.description: Consumers take time to adjust behavior. Short-term elasticity may differ from long-term. Allow time for demand to stabilize.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Other Factors
commonMistakes.description: Demand changes may be due to seasonality, competition, or economy, not just your price change. Control for other variables.

commonMistakes.title: Assuming Constant Elasticity
commonMistakes.description: Elasticity varies at different price points. A product may be inelastic at low prices but elastic at high prices.

commonMistakes.title: Confusing Revenue with Profit
commonMistakes.description: Elasticity predicts revenue impact. Profit depends on margins too. Lower prices may increase revenue but reduce profit.

faqs.question: What does elastic vs inelastic mean?
faqs.answer: Elastic demand (>1) is price-sensitive - quantity changes more than price. Inelastic (<1) is price-insensitive - quantity changes less. At exactly 1, changes are proportional.

faqs.question: How do I use elasticity for pricing?
faqs.answer: If demand is elastic, lower prices increase revenue. If inelastic, raise prices. Unitary elasticity means revenue stays same regardless of price.

faqs.question: What products are typically elastic?
faqs.answer: Luxuries, products with substitutes, big purchases, and non-essentials. Examples: vacations, brand-name goods, new cars.

faqs.question: What products are typically inelastic?
faqs.answer: Necessities, addictive goods, products without substitutes, and small purchases. Examples: gasoline, medicine, salt.

faqs.question: What is cross-price elasticity?
faqs.answer: Measures how demand for your product changes when a competitor or related product changes price. Positive for substitutes, negative for complements.

howItWorks.formula: Discounted Price = Base Price × (1 - Discount Percentage / 100)
howItWorks.explanation: Bulk pricing offers lower per-unit prices for larger quantities. Each tier defines quantity ranges and corresponding discounts. The calculator helps determine which tier offers the best value and whether ordering more to reach the next tier makes economic sense.

useCases.description: Compare volume discount structures from different suppliers to select the best overall value.

useCases.title: Order Optimization
useCases.description: Determine if ordering slightly more to reach the next tier saves money despite buying extra units.

useCases.title: Inventory Planning
useCases.description: Balance bulk discount savings against storage costs and cash flow requirements.

useCases.title: Pricing Strategy
useCases.description: Design effective tiered pricing structures that incentivize larger orders while maintaining profitability.

seoTips: Calculate total cost at tier thresholds to find true breakpoints
Include storage and carrying costs when evaluating larger purchases
Consider cash flow impact of larger upfront purchases
Combine orders with partners or colleagues to reach better tiers
Watch for expiration dates - bulk savings mean nothing if products expire

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Carrying Costs
commonMistakes.description: Bulk savings may be offset by storage, insurance, and capital tied up in inventory. Calculate true total cost.

commonMistakes.title: Buying Beyond Need
commonMistakes.description: Reaching a higher tier isn't worthwhile if you can't use the extra units. Waste eliminates savings.

commonMistakes.title: Missing Tier Breakpoints
commonMistakes.description: Ordering just below a tier threshold is worst value. Check if a few more units reaches better pricing.

commonMistakes.title: Not Comparing Total Costs
commonMistakes.description: A higher discount percentage doesn't always mean lowest total cost. Calculate actual dollars spent.

faqs.question: When should I order more to reach the next tier?
faqs.answer: When the savings at the next tier exceed the cost of extra units. Calculate: (Extra units × New price) vs (Original quantity × Old price - New price).

faqs.question: How do I compare suppliers with different tier structures?
faqs.answer: Calculate total cost at your typical order quantities for each supplier. The lowest total cost wins, not the highest discount percentage.

faqs.question: Should I always buy in bulk?
faqs.answer: Not always. Consider storage costs, spoilage/obsolescence, cash flow, and whether you'll actually use the quantity before expiration or technology changes.

faqs.question: What's a typical bulk discount structure?
faqs.answer: Common structures: 5% at 10 units, 10% at 25 units, 15% at 50 units, 20% at 100+ units. Varies widely by industry and product.

faqs.question: Can I negotiate better bulk pricing?
faqs.answer: Often yes, especially for large orders. Ask about price matching, combined shipping discounts, or contract pricing for regular orders.

howItWorks.explanation: Retirement savings grow through both contributions and compound interest. The calculator projects how current savings plus regular contributions grow over time at an expected rate of return. Compound interest means your earnings generate more earnings.

useCases.title: Savings Rate Planning
useCases.description: Calculate how much you need to save monthly to reach a specific retirement goal.

useCases.description: Compare outcomes at different expected returns to understand risk/reward tradeoffs.

useCases.title: Retirement Timeline
useCases.description: Determine if you can retire earlier or if you need to extend your working years.

seoTips: Historically, stock market returns average 7-10% annually; use 7% for conservative estimates
Increase contributions with raises - even 1% more annually compounds significantly
Starting early matters more than contribution amount due to compound interest
Account for inflation - you'll need 2-3x more in 30 years for same purchasing power
Consider tax-advantaged accounts (401k, IRA) which grow tax-deferred

commonMistakes.title: Unrealistic Return Assumptions
commonMistakes.description: Using 10-12% returns ignores market volatility and fees. Use 6-7% for conservative planning.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Inflation
commonMistakes.description: A million dollars in 30 years won't buy what it does today. Adjust your goal for expected inflation.

commonMistakes.title: Not Increasing Contributions
commonMistakes.description: Fixed contributions lose purchasing power over time. Increase with salary raises to maintain real savings rate.

commonMistakes.title: Underestimating Retirement Duration
commonMistakes.description: Plan for 30+ years of retirement. Running out of money at 85 is a real risk with increasing longevity.

faqs.question: How much do I need for retirement?
faqs.answer: Common rule: 25x annual expenses (4% withdrawal rate). If you spend $50,000/year, target $1.25 million. Adjust for Social Security and pensions.

faqs.question: What rate of return should I use?
faqs.answer: Conservative: 5-6%. Moderate: 7%. Aggressive: 8-9%. Use lower rates as you approach retirement when you should be more conservative.

faqs.question: When should I start saving for retirement?
faqs.answer: As early as possible. Starting at 25 vs 35 can mean twice as much at retirement due to compound interest - time is your biggest advantage.

faqs.question: What is the 4% rule?
faqs.answer: Research suggests withdrawing 4% of savings annually has a high probability of lasting 30+ years. So $1M allows ~$40K/year withdrawals.

faqs.question: How do I account for Social Security?
faqs.answer: Estimate your Social Security benefit and subtract from needed income. You need to save enough to cover the gap between Social Security and total needs.

seoTips: Always contribute at least enough to get the full employer match - it's an instant 50-100% return
2024 contribution limit is $23,000 ($30,500 if 50+); aim to maximize if possible
Employer matches don't count toward your contribution limit
Consider Roth 401(k) if available and you expect higher taxes in retirement
Increase contribution by 1% annually to reach higher savings rates painlessly

commonMistakes.title: Not Getting Full Match
commonMistakes.description: Leaving employer match money on the table is like refusing a raise. Always contribute enough to get 100% of available match.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Vesting Schedule
commonMistakes.description: Employer matches may vest over 3-6 years. Know your vesting schedule before counting matched funds as yours.

commonMistakes.title: Setting and Forgetting
commonMistakes.description: Increase contributions with raises. A 3% raise should include 0.5-1% increase to 401(k) contribution.

commonMistakes.title: Poor Investment Selection
commonMistakes.description: Default investment may be too conservative or have high fees. Review fund options and choose appropriate allocation.

faqs.question: What is employer matching?
faqs.answer: Employer contributes to your 401(k) based on your contribution. Common match: 50% of your contribution up to 6% of salary. So 6% contribution gets 3% employer match.

faqs.question: How much should I contribute to 401(k)?
faqs.answer: At minimum, enough to get full employer match. Ideally 15-20% of income including match. Max out ($23,000 in 2024) if you can afford it.

faqs.question: What is 401(k) vesting?
faqs.answer: Vesting determines when employer match becomes yours. You may need to work 3-6 years to be fully vested. Your contributions are always 100% yours.

faqs.question: Traditional vs Roth 401(k)?
faqs.answer: Traditional: Pre-tax contributions, taxed at withdrawal. Roth: After-tax contributions, tax-free withdrawal. Choose based on current vs expected future tax rates.

faqs.question: Can I withdraw early from 401(k)?
faqs.answer: Early withdrawal (before 59.5) incurs 10% penalty plus income tax. Exceptions exist for hardship, disability, and certain other situations.

ltv.title: Calculator
ltv.description: Calculate Loan-to-Value (LTV) ratio for mortgages and loans. LTV is a key metric lenders use to assess risk and determine loan terms.

inputs.property_value_tooltip: The appraised or purchase value of the property

errors.loan_exceeds_property: Loan amount cannot exceed property value

results.pmi_explanation: LTV above 80% typically requires Private Mortgage Insurance (PMI).
results.no_pmi_explanation: LTV at or below 80% typically does not require PMI.

risk_explanations.low: Excellent LTV ratio. You have significant equity and should qualify for the best loan terms and interest rates.
risk_explanations.moderate: Good LTV ratio, but PMI may be required. Consider a larger down payment to reach 80% LTV.
risk_explanations.high: Higher risk loan. Expect higher interest rates and PMI requirements. May have difficulty qualifying.
risk_explanations.very_high: Very high risk. May not qualify for conventional loans. Consider government-backed loan programs.

info.title: About LTV Calculator
info.ltv_range_low: 80% or below: Low risk, best rates, no PMI
info.ltv_range_very_high: 95%+: Very high risk, may need special programs

howItWorks.title: How LTV Calculation Works
howItWorks.formula: LTV = (Loan Amount / Property Value) × 100%
howItWorks.explanation: Loan-to-Value ratio compares your loan amount to the property's appraised value. Lower LTV means more equity and less risk for lenders, resulting in better rates and no PMI requirement. Higher LTV means less down payment but higher costs and stricter qualification.

useCases.title: Mortgage Planning
useCases.description: Determine required down payment to reach target LTV and qualify for best mortgage rates.

useCases.title: PMI Assessment
useCases.description: Calculate if Private Mortgage Insurance is required and how much down payment eliminates it.

useCases.title: Refinancing Analysis
useCases.description: Assess current equity position to determine eligibility for refinancing and PMI removal.

useCases.title: Home Equity Access
useCases.description: Calculate how much equity can be accessed through HELOC or home equity loan.

seoTips: 80% LTV is the magic number - below this typically means no PMI required
Lower LTV generally results in better interest rates
Appraisal value may differ from purchase price - lender uses lower of the two
Combined LTV (CLTV) includes all loans secured by the property
FHA loans allow up to 96.5% LTV; VA loans allow 100% LTV

commonMistakes.title: Using Purchase Price Instead of Appraisal
commonMistakes.description: Lenders use the lower of purchase price or appraised value. An appraisal below purchase price increases your LTV.

commonMistakes.title: Forgetting About PMI Cost
commonMistakes.description: PMI at higher LTV can cost $100-300/month. Calculate total monthly payment, not just principal and interest.

commonMistakes.title: Ignoring Combined LTV
commonMistakes.description: If you have a HELOC or second mortgage, combined LTV matters. All loans against the property count.

commonMistakes.title: Not Planning for 80% Threshold
commonMistakes.description: Getting close to 80% but not reaching it still requires PMI. Better to hit exactly 80% than 81%.

faqs.question: What is a good LTV ratio?
faqs.answer: 80% or below is ideal - no PMI, best rates. 80-90% is acceptable but requires PMI. Above 90% is high risk with higher rates.

faqs.question: What is PMI and why does LTV matter?
faqs.answer: Private Mortgage Insurance protects lenders if you default. Required when LTV exceeds 80%. Costs 0.5-1% of loan annually until you reach 80% equity.

faqs.question: How do I lower my LTV?
faqs.answer: Make a larger down payment, pay down principal faster, or wait for property appreciation. Refinancing after significant principal paydown or appreciation can help.

faqs.question: When can I remove PMI?
faqs.answer: When LTV reaches 80% through payments, or automatically removed at 78% LTV. You can request removal at 80% with good payment history.

faqs.question: Does LTV affect my interest rate?
faqs.answer: Yes. Lower LTV usually means lower rates. Rates may improve at 80%, 75%, and 60% LTV thresholds depending on lender.
